attributes.title: Barriers and facilitators to the implementation of nutrition standards for school food: a mixed methods systematic review protocol.
attributes.description: This mixed methods systematic review aims to address this evidence gap by synthesising the empirical evidence on the factors that may influence implementation of school food standards.

summary.value: A number of studies have identified various factors that affect the implementation of school food standards, however, to the best of our knowledge, there has been no previous systematic review undertaken in this area. Seward and colleagues’ systematic review analysed the implementation of dietary guidelines, however this was in relation to childcare services. Given this evidence gap, the primary aim of the systematic review is to collate the factors that influence the implementation of nutrition or food standards for school food provision in primary and post primary settings (children aged 5-18 years). The use of the TDF will ensure a comprehensive range of implementation factors are examined. Using a theory provides a strong foundation for policy development, in contrast to simply identifying the barriers and facilitators. Understanding these factors from a theoretical perspective will provide a list of modifiable factors to target. This will help to inform future planning, improve uptake and practice of standards. Essentially, this review can guide policy makers, researchers and individuals responsible for devising and implementing nutrition standards in schools.

attributes.title: Life Goal Development and Occupational Creativity
attributes.description:
Summary: This registration document contains the analysis plan for existing longitudinal data as part of a project assessing longitudinal changes in life goals and their relationships with occupational creativity. This project will use data from two existing datasets. The project has two primary goals: (1) to examine how life goals develop and change during adolescence and young adulthood and (2) to examine whether changes in goals (over and above initial levels) predict occupational creativity. 
We follow 2 steps in preregistering this project. At step 1, we registered our analysis plan for factor analyses to determine the structure of the life goals measure employed in the study. At step 2 (current document), we register hypotheses and research questions for the main study. Both registration documents follow the preregistration template, “Preregistration of secondary data analysis: A template and tutorial” (den Akker et al., 2019).

attributes.title: Mothership versus Drip-and-Ship model for mechanical thrombectomy in acute stroke treatment: a systematic review for clinical and radiological outcome
attributes.description: Mechanical thrombectomy is effective in the acute ischemic stroke treatment due to large vessel occlusion. However, all facilities to perform this procedure are available only in few centers (Hub). To date, it is not clear if the direct transport of these patients to the Hub centers (mothership) are more effective than a primary transport to the other hospitals without all facilites (spoke) and subsequently transferred to the Hub centers (drip and ship). We aimed with this pooled analysis to investigate what type of organizational model is better for the functional outcome of ischemic stroke patients.

summary.value: By this analysis, we would like to investigate how the direct admission of patients with acute ischemic stroke due to large vessel occlusion to a hub center (Mothership) influence the clinical and radiological outcome, when compared to patients firstly referred to a Spoke center and then transferred to the Hub (drip and ship).

registration_responses.summary: By this analysis, we would like to investigate how the direct admission of patients with acute ischemic stroke due to large vessel occlusion to a hub center (Mothership) influence the clinical and radiological outcome, when compared to patients firstly referred to a Spoke center and then transferred to the Hub (drip and ship).

attributes.title: Being moved and attachment
attributes.description: The emotion often denoted as "being moved" has often been supposed to be linked to the attachment system (e.g. Panksepp, 1995). However, this relationship has not yet been explored empirically. In a previous study, we found that attachment as a trait (measured with the Adult Attachment Questionnaire and the Relationships Questionnaire) was related to the propensity of a participant to be moved by a video and to be moved in general (as measured by the Geneva Sentimentality Scale). In this study, we are interested on the impact of the being moved emotion on attachment state.

q1.value: Effects of being moved on attachment state

q3.value: The emotion often denoted as "being moved" has often been supposed to be linked to the attachment system (e.g. Panksepp, 1995). However, this relationship has not yet been explored empirically. In a previous study, we found that attachment as a trait (measured with the Adult Attachment Questionnaire and the Relationships Questionnaire) was related to the propensity of a participant to be moved by a video and to be moved in general (as measured by the Geneva Sentimentality Scale). In this study, we are interested on the impact of the being moved emotion on attachment state.

q4.value:
H1. (non-directional) Inducing feelings of being moved has an impact on the attachment state.

H2. (non-directional) Attachment trait and caregiving trait modulate the influence that of induction of "being moved" on attachment state. 

3. (non-directional) The bodily phenomenon known as chills (cf. Maruskin, 2012) is a mediator of the impact of induction of "being moved" on the attachment state.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: The design will be experimental and between-subjects. Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: Moving, Happy, Neutral and Sad (see stimuli section), and will listen to a piece of music of approximately 1 min.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The experiment will be run on-line on the platform Qualtrics. Participants will sign up for the experiment and read and sign an online consent form. They will also be asked to take the study in a quiet place with earphones or headphones. 

The design will be experimental and between-subjects. Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of four music conditions: Moving, Happy, Neutral and Sad, and will listen to a piece of music of approximately 1 min. Afterwards, the participant will be asked to answer questions concerning the experience of chills (Maruski, Thrash,  & Elliot, 2012):

While listening to this music, to which extent did you…
...feel cold or feel a chill 
…feel a shiver or shudder
…have a tingling or ticklish feeling
…have goosebumps or a hair-on-end feeling”
On a scale from 1 = not at all to 7=very strongly.

Participants will also be asked to rate to which extent they felt 13 emotions. The 13 emotions are: amusement, anger, awe, compassion, contentment, gratitude, fear, I felt moved, I felt touched, joy, pride, sadness and wonder, and will be rated on a scale from 1=not at all to 5=very strongly.

The participant will then be asked to fill 4 questionnaires: the State Adult Attachment Measure (SAAM), the Caregiving System Scale (CSS), the Experiences in Close Relationships Scale (ECR) and the Geneva Sentimentality Scale.

Finally, participants will answer demographic questions and participate in an exploratory study in which they will again be randomly assigned to two conditions: social priming and no social priming. They will again hear a piece of music (the same for everybody) and answer the chills, emotions and SAAM again. The difference between the 2 conditions will be the text introducing the music: half of the participants will be told it is a recording from a musician playing at a wedding (social priming) and half will be told it was created by a compositor using only a computer (no social priming). A brief statement will afterwards explain the deception and let the participant choose to include the data or not in the study

q13.value: We decided to recruit 80 participants for each condition (sad, happy and neutral music), except the Moving condition for which there will be 160 participants, for a total of 400 participants.

q14.value: This sample size was determined on the basis of funds available to us, and based on the fact that further analysis will be done comparing moving music to non-moving music, requiring more participants in the moving condition.

question.value: We will manipulate the type of music with 4 levels: happy, sad, neutral and moving (characterization based on previous studies). There will be 3 stimuli for each condition, to control for characteristics bonded to a specific stimulus.

Emotions: intensity of 13 emotions felt while listening to the music. Participants will be asked to rate on a scale from 1 to 5 the intensity of 13 emotions: amusement, anger, awe, compassion, contentment, gratitude, fear, I felt moved, I felt touched, joy, pride, sadness and wonder

Chills: experience of the bodily sensation known as "chills" while listening to the music. Participants will rate on a scale from 1 to 7 to which extent they experienced a chill, shiver or shudder, a tingling or ticklish feeling and goosebumps or a hair-on-end feeling (based on the study of Maruskin, L. A., Thrash, T. M., & Elliot, A. J. 2012)

Attachment state:  attachment as a state is defined as the state of fluctuation of the attachment style of a person. Even though the attachment style (trait) is a relatively stable characteristic, it can have fluctuations in specific situations in which for example security is primed. Attachment state will be measured by the State Adult Attachment Measure developed by Gillath, Hart, Noftle & Stockdale (2009). This scale has 3 different subscales: anxiety, avoidance and security. 

Attachment trait: attachment as a trait is considered a stable characteristic of an individual concerning his style of feeling and behaving in close relationships. It will be measured with the Experience in Close Relationships Questionnaire (cf. Brennan, K. A., Clark, C. L., & Shaver, P. R. 1998) that has two subscales: avoidance and anxiety.

Caregiving trait: the caregiving system is considered the counterpart of the attachment system. Caregiving as a trait is considered to be the (relatively stable) style of caregiving of an individual. This trait will be measured with the Caregiving System Scale developed by Shaver, Mikulincer, & Shemesh-Iron, (2010) that allows the calculation of two scores: the caregiving deactivation and the caregiving hyperactivation.

Chills:
The four questions will give 4 different scores for goosebumps, tingling, coldness and shivers. If the correlations between goosebumps and tingling and between coldness and shivers is significant, they will be combined (added) to create two additional indices: Goosetingles and Coldshivers (cf. Maruskin, 2012).   

Emotions:
The score on each emotion will be considered an indice. If correlation between being moved and being touched is significant, the two will be averaged to create the being moved/touched indice. 

State Adult Attachment Measure (SAAM):
From the 21 items composing this scale, three indices will be calculated:
1. The Avoidant Attachment score is computed by averaging items 2, 3, 9, 10, 15, 16, and
21.
2. The Attachment Anxiety score is computed by averaging items 1, 5, 8, 12, 14, 17, and 19.
3. The Attachment Security score is computed by averaging items 4, 6, 7, 11, 13, 18, and 20.

Experience in close relationships Scale (ECR):
From the 36 items composing this scale, two indices will be calculated:
1. The Avoidant Attachment score is computed by averaging the 18 odd-numbered (1, 3, 5,
etc.) items. Higher scores reflect greater avoidance.
2. The Attachment Anxiety score is computed by averaging the 18 even-numbered items (2,
4, 6, etc.). Higher scores reflect greater anxiety.
(Note. Items 3, 15, 19, 22, 25, 27, 29, 31, 33, and 35 must be reverse-keyed prior to computing the scores)

Caregiving System Scale:
From the 20 items composing this scale, two indices will be calculated:
1. The Caregiving Deactivation score is computed by averaging the 10 odd-numbered (1, 3,
5, etc.) items. Higher scores reflect greater deactivation of the caregiving system.
2. The Caregiving Hyperactivation score is computed by averaging the 10 even-numbered
items (2, 4, 6, etc.). Higher scores reflect greater hyperactivation of the caregiving system.

Geneva Sentimentality Scale:
From the 10 items composing this scale, 3 indices will be calculated:
1. Emotions labels will be calculated by averaging items 1, 2 and 3 (reverse coded).
2. Tears of joy index will be calculated by averaging items 4, 5, 6 and 7
3. Warm feelings in the chest will be calculated by averaging items 8, 9 and 10

*Impact of music on state attachment
To analyze the impact of each condition on the attachment state, three one-way ANOVAs will be performed, using music conditions as factors and the 3 separate scores on the three different subscales of the State Adult Attachment Measure (Anxiety, Avoidance and Security) as dependent-variables. Post-hoc Tukey tests will be used whenever ANOVA returns a significant effect of the music condition on scores to the SAAM.. 

*Moderators of the impact of music on state attachment
To determine whether attachment trait (as measured through ECR) and caregiving trait (as measured through the Caregiving System Scale) moderate the effect of music condition on attachment state, we will perform a linear mixed model with music condition (two levels: moving music vs. non-moving music) as a predictor, attachment state as a dependent variable, and scores to the two subscales of ECR and two subscales of CSS as moderators.

*Do chills mediate the impact of music on state attachment?
Finally, we will use a multiple regression analysis to investigate whether the effect of music condition (two levels: moving vs. non-moving music) on attachment state is mediated by participants’ reports of chills. Questions about chills will be averaged to form two different scores (Questions 1 & 2 vs. Questions 3 & 4), which means we will test for two different mediators.

q20.value:
To be sure that our stimuli work how they are supposed to, we will compare the scores for each of the 13 emotions and the experience of chills across the four conditions. We will use an ANOVA first, followed by a post-hoc Tukey test in case the ANOVA returns a significant difference between our groups.

Participants’ reports of feeling ‘moved’ and ‘touched’ will be aggregated in a single score. We expect this score to be significantly lower than midpoint for the Happy and Neutral conditions, and to be significantly higher than midpoint for the Moving condition. These hypotheses will be tested using t-tests. For the Sad condition, we will first test whether this score is significantly lower than the midpoint. If it is, the Sad condition will be considered as a ‘non-Moving’ condition for subsequent analyses (see above). If it isn’t, we will compare these scores between the Moving and Sad condition. If these scores do not significantly differ between these two conditions, the Sad condition will be considered as a ‘Moving’ condition for subsequent analyses. If they do, the Sad condition will be excluded from linear mixed model and multiple regression analyses (see above).

q21.value: All inferences will be done on the basis of a p < 0.05.

q22.value: We will exclude from analysis participants who failed the Attention Questions from the being moved questionnaire (“Please pick option 5" and "please pick option 2" )

q23.value: Participants with missing data will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value:
Concerning the exploratory study at the end of the questionnaire, conventional t-tests will be performed to compare the two conditions (social priming and no social priming) on participants' scores for the 13 emotions, the experience of chills and the SAAM.

To determine the validity of GSS, we will test to which extent participants' scores to the GSS predict the extent to which they feel moved/touched by moving music.

attributes.title: Positive Emotionality Structure Project
attributes.description: Please see the attached document for a full description of the proposed analyses and datasets.  In summary, the primary goal of this research is to inform how positive emotional experiences should be classified and assessed in future research.  As a related secondary aim, we are interested in demonstrating that distinct types of positive emotional experiences (e.g., feeling enthusiastic versus experiencing gratitude) show differential patterns of correlates with well-being, personality, and psychiatric symptoms.  The datasets collected for this research (i.e., 447 undergraduates and 375 community adults) represent a cross-sectional, observational study.

summary.value: Please see the attached files for a description of this research, including a description of the study datasets, proposed analyses, and other relevant information.  Institutional ethics board permission was not obtained to share study datasets online, although all study data are available upon request.  Please contact Kasey Stanton at kaseyjstanton@gmail.com with any requests or questions.

registration_responses.summary: Please see the attached files for a description of this research, including a description of the study datasets, proposed analyses, and other relevant information.  Institutional ethics board permission was not obtained to share study datasets online, although all study data are available upon request.  Please contact Kasey Stanton at kaseyjstanton@gmail.com with any requests or questions.

attributes.title: Predicting and correcting the influence of Covid-19 and pro-chloroquine conspiracy theories on Covid-19 vaccination intentions
attributes.description: Experimental study. Our goal is to predict and correct the influence of Covid-19 and pro-chloroquine conspiracy theories on Covid-19 vaccination intentions in France.

q1.value: Paul Bertin, Sylvain Delouvée, Kenzo Nera

q2.value:
Correlational part: 
H1..1 Covid-19 CTs predict negative attitudes toward vaccination
H1.2. Covid-19 CTs predict negative attitudes toward Covid-19 vaccination
H2.1. pro-chloroquine conspiracy beliefs predict negative attitudes toward vaccination
H2.2. pro-chloroquine conspiracy beliefs predict negative attitudes toward Covid-19 vaccination
 
Experimental part : 
H1. We hypothesize that both experimental tasks (correction and empowerment) will result in an increase of vaccination intention compared to the control condition
H2. This effect will be mediated by decreased endorsement of pro-chloroquine conspiracy theories

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value: The first part of the study is correlational. All participants will answer to the same questions. The second part is experimental, with the participant being randomly assigned to one of the three conditions (correction condition vs empowerment condition vs control control). After the experimental task, they will complete the DV and mediator scales.

q7.value: The randomization will take part we assigning the participant to one of the three conditions.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will collect dara from the survey implemented on Qualtrics. Participants recruited by the mean of Facebook Sponsored advertisements. We will look for a sample representative of the French population applying Zhang et al. (2018) quota sampling method. 

Inclusion criteria are: French nationality, French fluency, having properly completed the validity check and seriousness check, having completed the survey. 

We will calculate the Median Absolute Deviation (MAD; Leys, Ley, Klein, Bernard & Licata, 2013) to detect outliers on the questionnaire completion time. We will exclude participant falling outside a 3MAD interval range. 

Participant will not be payed for their participation.

q11.value: Our target sample size is 1269 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 1400 participants anticipating for exclusion criterion drop-out.

q12.value: In order to detect a small effect by Cohen’s standards (d = .20) with a power of .90 in an ANOVA with three between-subjects conditions and a classic alpha level of .05, 1269 participants are needed, which is roughly the size of a nationally representative sample

q13.value: We will stop the data collection when N = 1400 will be reached.

question.value:
Condition 1: Correction of conspiracy belief. Following Lyons and colleagues (2019), participants in this group will read a text 'correcting' pro-chloroquine conspiracy theories' arguments.
Condition 2: empowerment about the pandemic situation. Following Van Prooijen (2018), participants in this group will read a text with arguments intended to empower them about the pandemic situation, using procedural justice criteria. 
Condition 3: control group. Participants in this group will read a neutral text describing the pandemic situation (control condition inspired by the one used by Lyons and colleagues, 2019).

Note that some scales were created by the authors for the planned study. Items will be pretested to check the reliability of the scales. As a result, items might be slightly modified in the following days.

Conspiracy beliefs about Covid-19: we will use 10 designed items and used in a preliminary study (see Material - study 1). We found good internal consistency and a two factor structure (ingroup and outgroup conspiracy theories). 
Conspiracy beliefs pro-chloroquine: we will use a scale made of 4 items designed for this study purpose (see Material - study 2). 
Vaccination intentions: we will use a translated and adapted version of the single item used by Jolley and Douglas (2017).

Attitude toward vaccination : we will use a translated version of Lewandowsky, Gignac and Oberauer's (2013) 5 items scale that we previously used in its 3 items form (see Material - study 1). 
Attitude toward chloroquine: we will use a scale made of 4 items designed for this study purpose (see Material - study 2).
Demographic questions (age, gender, education level, political orientation)
If the internal consistency is acceptable (i.e >.70), a score will be calculated by averaging the items for each scales.

For the correlation part, we will use a regression analysis. 


For the experimental part, we will use an ANOVA model, applying contrast if the omnibus test is significant. 

For mediation analyses, we will use the "lavaan" R package (Rosseel, 2018).

q19.value: As this study is confirmatory, we will use one tailed tests for each analyses. We will use a conventional p < .05 inference criteria.

q20.value: See previously point about exclusion criterion.

registration_responses.q2:
Correlational part: 
H1..1 Covid-19 CTs predict negative attitudes toward vaccination
H1.2. Covid-19 CTs predict negative attitudes toward Covid-19 vaccination
H2.1. pro-chloroquine conspiracy beliefs predict negative attitudes toward vaccination
H2.2. pro-chloroquine conspiracy beliefs predict negative attitudes toward Covid-19 vaccination
 
Experimental part : 
H1. We hypothesize that both experimental tasks (correction and empowerment) will result in an increase of vaccination intention compared to the control condition
H2. This effect will be mediated by decreased endorsement of pro-chloroquine conspiracy theories

attributes.title: Detecting Bullshit: The Roles of  Topic Complexity and Response Latency
attributes.description: Bullshitting is defined as communicating with little to no concern for evidence of truth (Frankfurt, 1986), which is distinguished from lying that entails a deliberate manipulation and subversion of truth (Pennycook, Cheyne, Barr, Koehler, & Fugelsang, 2015). Very little is known about the conditions under which people successfully detect bullshit in others or the social cues they use in the way of detection. The current investigation is designed to examine the roles of two potentially useful social cues that people may use to detect bullshit: topic complexity and response latency.

q2.value:
Both Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 systematically manipulate the topic complexity for the communicator and perceived response latency and examines how these variables may interact to affect social perception of bullshitting behaviors.  

It is hypothesized that communications regarding complex, rather than simple, topics are expected to receive longer, rather than shorter, response latencies.  When this expectation is met (i.e., relatively greater response latency when the topic is complex, or shorter response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as evidence rather than bullshit.  On the other hand, when this expectation is not met (i.e., relatively shorter response latency when the topic is complex, or longer response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as bullshit rather than evidence.  In other words, perceived topic complexity is expected to interact with perceived response latency to affect socially perceived bullshit.  Therefore, neither the topic complexity nor the response latency alone is hypothesized to produce a significant main effect on socially perceived bullshitting behavior, but rather the interactive effect of topic complexity and response latency is hypothesized to influence people’s perception of others’ bullshit.

q3.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Experiment 2 will employ a 2 (Topic Complexity: simple vs. complex) × 2 (Response Latency: short delay/fast vs. long delay/slow) between-subjects factorial design.

q7.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions manipulating Topic Complexity and Response Latency.  

Topic Complexity. The content of the chat will consist of a simulated conversation about Economy. The topic of the discussion will be introduced as one that is either simple or complex for the communicators.  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the simple condition, where the Responder (i.e., Bob) claims that the topic is “pretty simple”.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the complex condition, where Bob claims that the topic is “pretty complex”.  

Response Latency. Participants will be led to believe the text chat was pre-recorded in real time so as to make salient the response latency element.  The answers that the Responder (i.e., Bob) provides will be displayed (“typed”) in either fast speed (i.e. with shorter response latencies) or slow speed (i.e. with longer response latencies), which simulates the display of how long it took the Responder to generate answers to the Questioner (i.e., Joan)’s questions.  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the short delay/fast condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with a few, short pauses.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the long delay/slow condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with multiple, longer pauses. While the Response Latency is different, the content of the answers will be the same across all conditions.

q8.value: Registration prior to any human observation of the data

question.value:
The experiments will be programmed using Qualtrics software and will be conducted online. A total of 400 US participants will be recruited via Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) to participate in the Experiment 2. 

Participants will be required to have a Human Intelligence Tasks (HITs) Approval Rate of at least 95% to ensure the quality of the data (Peer, Vosgerau, & Acquisti, 2014).  Each participant will receive one US dollar for participating in the study.  Each participant will complete the entire procedure in under 30 minutes. Participants who participated in experiment 1 will not have access to participate in experiment 2.

q11.value: A total of 400 US participants will participate in Experiment 1.

q12.value:
The sample size is determined based on the recommendations of statisticians (Lakens & Evers, 2014; Simmons, Nelson, & Simonsohn, 2013), who advocated using an n = 50 per condition as a rule of thumb.  Accordingly, we will attempt to get at least 50 participants per between-subjects condition of our design.  

An a priori power analysis using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) revealed a required sample size of N = 260 (n = 65 per condition) to detect a small to medium effect (f2 = .175)  in an analysis of variance (ANOVA) test with acceptable power of 1 – β = .80.  

The sample size was also balanced by the time and cost limit (Dattalo, 2008). Correspondingly, a sample of 400 online (MTurk) respondents will be recruited to participate in order to ensure the quality of the data.  Each participant will receive one US dollar for participating in the study.

question.value:
Topic Complexity. The content of the chat will consist of a simulated conversation about Economy. The topic of the discussion will be introduced as one that is either simple or complex for the communicators (see Appendix A).  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the simple condition, where the Responder (i.e., Bob) claims that the topic is “pretty simple”.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the complex condition, where Bob claims that the topic is “pretty complex”.  

Response Latency. Participants will be led to believe the text chat was pre-recorded in real time so as to make salient the response latency element.  The answers that the Responder (i.e., Bob) provides will be displayed (“typed”) in either fast speed (i.e. with shorter response latencies) or slow speed (i.e. with longer response latencies), which simulates the display of how long it took the Responder to generate answers to the Questioner (i.e., Joan)’s questions.  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the short delay/fast condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with a few, short pauses.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the long delay/slow condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with multiple, longer pauses. While the Response Latency is different, the content of the answers will be the same across all conditions.

Following the video, participants will be asked questions concerning the video chat.

Perceived Topic Complexity. Participants will respond to “Based on the conversation, how complex was the topic for Bob?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (extremely simple) to 9 (extremely complex) as the anchor labels.

Perceived Bullshit. Participants will respond to the question “When Bob was answering how Economy works, to what degree do you think Bob was truly concerned with genuine evidence and/or established knowledge?” using a 0 (not at all concerned) to 10 (extremely concerned) response scale. Then, questions and answers in the conversation will be displayed again on the screen frame one pair at a time, and for each answer, participants will respond to the above question again.  Greater scores of the question indicate less perceived bullshit.

Expertise Evaluation. Participants will then be asked to evaluate the level of expertise they believe Bob has on the subject by answering five questions. For examples, “Based on the conversation, how much knowledge do you believe Bob has on the subject discussed in the chat video?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (less than a useful level of knowledge) to 9 (professional level of knowledge) as the anchor labels; and “Based on the conversation, to what extent do you agree that Bob has expertise on the subject discussed in the chat video?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (strongly disagree) to 9 (strongly agree) as the anchor labels.  Greater scores on the scale indicate higher evaluations of expertise. 

Perceived Response Latency, Background check, and the Realisticity of the chat video.   “Based on the conversation, how quickly did Bob respond to Joan’s questions?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (extremely slowly) to 9 (extremely quickly) as the anchor labels; "What was the background of the communicators in the video?"; and “How realistic did the chat video look?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (extremely unrealistic) to 9 (extremely realistic) as the anchor labels.

Knowledge of Topic. Participants will be asked to report their own knowledge of the subject (see Appendix I) by answering three questions. For example, participants will respond to “How familiar are you with the subject discussed in the chat video?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (not at all familiar) to 9 (extremely familiar) as the anchor labels; and “How much knowledge do you have on the subject discussed in the chat video?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (less than a useful level of knowledge) to 9 (professional level of knowledge) as the anchor labels.  Greater scores on the scale indicate more knowledge of the subject.  

At the conclusion of the study, participants will finish the demographic questionnaire, then be debriefed and thanked for their participation.

Total Bullshit Score. Total Bullshit Scores will be calculated by first reverse-scoring the Perceived Bullshit Scale, then summing all the reversed scores, resulting in possible bullshit scores of 0-40. 

Primary Analysis. A 2 × 2 ANOVA will be conducted to examine the effects of Topic Complexity and Response Latency on Total Bullshit Score, and pending on the significances of the interaction, pairwise contrasts will be used to test the simple effects.  The main effect of Topic Complexity will not be significant, meaning that the complexity of the topic is not associated with the perceived bullshit.  The main effect of Response Latency will not be significant, meaning that there is no linear relationship between response latency and the perceived bullshit.  The interaction effect of Topic Complexity and Response Latency will be significant.  Pairwise contracts will find a significant simple effect of Response Latency in both complex condition and simple condition respectively, but in opposite directions (see Figure 1), meaning that when the topic is complex, fast responses will be more likely to be perceived as bullshit than slow responses; while when the topic is simple, slow responses will be more likely to be perceived as bullshit than fast responses.

Additional Analysis. Pearson’s correlations will be tested between Total Bullshit Score and the Expertise Evaluation, and the results will find significant negative correlations.  The more bullshitting behavior the participants perceived from the conversation, the lower level of expertise they will evaluate the Responder (i.e., Bob) to have. 

Exploratory Analysis. A 2 × 2 ANCOVA will be conducted to examine the effects of Topic Complexity and Response Latency on Total Bullshit Score controlling for Knowledge of Topic.  And pending on the significances of the interaction, pairwise contrasts will be used to test the simple effects.  The results of the analysis will not alter any patterns or conclusions that will be found in the primary analysis and will reveal the aforementioned interaction effects more clearly.

Manipulation Checks. T-tests will be conducted on questions of the Perceived Topic Complexity and Perceived Response Latency.  The results will confirm that the manipulations of Topic Complexity and Response Latency are effective.  People who fail the “realistic” question will be excluded and all previous analyses will be reconducted.

attributes.title: Detecting Bullshit: The Roles of  Topic Complexity and Response Latency
attributes.description: Bullshitting is defined as communicating with little to no concern for evidence of truth (Frankfurt, 1986), which is distinguished from lying that entails a deliberate manipulation and subversion of truth (Pennycook, Cheyne, Barr, Koehler, & Fugelsang, 2015). Very little is known about the conditions under which people successfully detect bullshit in others or the social cues they use in the way of detection. The current investigation is designed to examine the roles of two potentially useful social cues that people may use to detect bullshit: topic complexity and response latency.

q2.value:
Both Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 systematically manipulate the topic complexity for the communicator and perceived response latency and examines how these variables may interact to affect social perception of bullshitting behaviors.  It is hypothesized that communications regarding complex, rather than simple, topics are expected to receive longer, rather than shorter, response latencies.  When this expectation is met (i.e., relatively greater response latency when the topic is complex, or shorter response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as evidence rather than bullshit.  On the other hand, when this expectation is not met (i.e., relatively shorter response latency when the topic is complex, or longer response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as bullshit rather than evidence.  In other words, perceived topic complexity is expected to interact with perceived response latency to affect socially perceived bullshit.  Therefore, neither the topic complexity nor the response latency alone is hypothesized to produce a significant main effect on socially perceived bullshitting behavior, but rather the interactive effect of topic complexity and response latency is hypothesized to influence people’s perception of others’ bullshit.

In order to test the interactive effect of topic complexity and response latency on socially perceived bullshit, it is critical to the design of the current research to employ a topic of discussion that clearly varies in its topic complexity as well as its perceived response latency.  To this end, Experiment 1 will serve as a pilot study to determine if simple and complex discussion conditions are perceived to be simple and complex respectively, and to confirm that the response latencies are perceived as short (fast) and long (slow). 

Because the hypotheses of the Experiment 2 are also based on the assumption that people generally believe that complex topics require significantly more time to explain relative to simpler topics, Experiment 1 was also designed to directly explore evidence supporting the assumption that a relationship between complexity and response latency is perceived to exist.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Experiment 1 will employ a 2 (Topic Complexity: simple vs. complex) × 2 (Response Latency: short delay/fast vs. long delay/slow) between-subjects factorial design. Questions regarding the Perceived Topic Complexity and Perceived Response Latency will serve as the dependent variables. The order of measuring Perceived Topic Complexity and Perceived Response Latency is counterbalanced.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four conditions manipulating Topic Complexity and Response Latency.  

Topic Complexity. The content of the chat will consist of a simulated conversation about Economy. The answers that the Responder (i.e., Bob) provides will be displayed (“typed”) in either fast speed (i.e. with shorter response latencies) or slow speed (i.e. with longer response latencies), which simulates the display of how long it took the Responder to generate answers to the Questioner (i.e., Joan)’s questions.  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the short delay/fast condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with a few, short pauses. question.value:
Topic Complexity. The content of the chat will consist of a simulated conversation about Economy. The topic of the discussion will be introduced as one that is either simple or complex for the communicators (see Appendix A).  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the simple condition, where the Responder (i.e., Bob) claims that the topic is “pretty simple”.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the complex condition, where Bob claims that the topic is “pretty complex”.  

Response Latency. Participants will be led to believe the text chat was pre-recorded in real time so as to make salient the response latency element.  The answers that the Responder (i.e., Bob) provides will be displayed (“typed”) in either fast speed (i.e. with shorter response latencies) or slow speed (i.e. with longer response latencies), which simulates the display of how long it took the Responder to generate answers to the Questioner (i.e., Joan)’s questions.  Half of the participants will be randomly assigned to the short delay/fast condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with a few, short pauses.  The other half of the participants will be assigned to the long delay/slow condition, where the Responder appears to type the answers with multiple, longer pauses. While the Response Latency is different, the content of the answers will be the same across all conditions.

Perceived Topic Complexity. Following the video, participants will be asked six questions concerning the Perceived Topic Complexity.  For example, participants will be asked, “Based on the conversation, how complex was the topic discussed in the chat video for Bob?” using a 9-point response scale with 1 (extremely simple) to 9 (extremely complex) as the anchor labels.  Greater scores of the scale indicate higher Topic Complexity.

Perceived Response Latency.  Participants will then be asked seven questions concerning the Perceived Response Latency of the text chat.  For example, participants will be asked, “Based on the conversation, how quickly did Bob respond to Joan’s questions?” using a 9-point response scale with 1 (extremely slowly) to 9 (extremely quickly) as the anchor labels.  Greater scores of the scale indicate longer Response Latency.

Social Expectation of the Association between Topic Complexity and Response Latency. Participants will be asked to report their belief of the relation between topic complexity and response latency by answering four questions including “Based on the conversation, how much time do you expect Bob to spend in order to adequately respond to a simple [complex] question?” and “In your opinion, how much time can a person be expected to spend in order to adequately respond to a simple [complex] question in general?”, using a 9-point response scale with 1 (very little time) to 9 (a lot of time) as the anchor labels.  The item regarding the simple question will be reverse scored.  Positive and greater scores on the scale indicate the belief that explaining relatively complex topics is associated with a longer delay and slower speed to respond, whereas simple topics are associated with briefer delays and faster speed to respond.

Last, participants will receive a demographic questionnaire, a debriefing message, and a thank-you message.

Perceived Topic Complexity and Perceived Response Latency. One-tailed independent t-tests will be conducted to examine the main effects of Topic Complexity and Response Latency on Perceived Topic Complexity and Perceived Response Latency, respectively.  The results will find that participants in the complex condition score significantly higher on the Perceived Topic Complexity Scale than those in the simple condition, and participants in the long delay/slow condition score significantly higher on the Perceived Response Latency Scale than those in the short delay/fast condition; both of which show that the manipulations work in the intended directions.  To ensure the manipulations that will be used in Experiment 2 are valid, Experiment 1 will be repeatedly conducted until statistically significant difference in Response Latency between the two Response Latency conditions and significant difference in Topic Complexity between the two Topic Complexity conditions are found.

Social Expectation of the Association between Topic Complexity and Response Latency Score. The Social Expectation Score will be calculated by reverse-scoring the second item and averaging the two scores.  It is expected that the descriptive statistics will show a general tendency of the belief that explaining complex topics is associated with slow response latencies and explaining simple topics is associated with fast speed response latencies (i.e., M > 0). A one-tailed single-sample t-test will be conducted to examine the difference between the mean score and the midpoint of the scale (0), and the result will show that the mean score is significantly larger than 0.

registration_responses.q2:
Both Experiment 1 and Experiment 2 systematically manipulate the topic complexity for the communicator and perceived response latency and examines how these variables may interact to affect social perception of bullshitting behaviors.  It is hypothesized that communications regarding complex, rather than simple, topics are expected to receive longer, rather than shorter, response latencies.  When this expectation is met (i.e., relatively greater response latency when the topic is complex, or shorter response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as evidence rather than bullshit.  On the other hand, when this expectation is not met (i.e., relatively shorter response latency when the topic is complex, or longer response latency when the topic is simple), responses are expected to be perceived as bullshit rather than evidence.  In other words, perceived topic complexity is expected to interact with perceived response latency to affect socially perceived bullshit.  Therefore, neither the topic complexity nor the response latency alone is hypothesized to produce a significant main effect on socially perceived bullshitting behavior, but rather the interactive effect of topic complexity and response latency is hypothesized to influence people’s perception of others’ bullshit.

In order to test the interactive effect of topic complexity and response latency on socially perceived bullshit, it is critical to the design of the current research to employ a topic of discussion that clearly varies in its topic complexity as well as its perceived response latency.  To this end, Experiment 1 will serve as a pilot study to determine if simple and complex discussion conditions are perceived to be simple and complex respectively, and to confirm that the response latencies are perceived as short (fast) and long (slow). 

Because the hypotheses of the Experiment 2 are also based on the assumption that people generally believe that complex topics require significantly more time to explain relative to simpler topics, Experiment 1 was also designed to directly explore evidence supporting the assumption that a relationship between complexity and response latency is perceived to exist.

attributes.title: Upgrade rate of Pure Flat Epithelial Atypia Diagnosed on Core Needle Biopsy: Systemic Review and Meta-Analysis
attributes.description: To perform a systematic review and meta-analysis to calculate the pooled upgrade rate of pure flat epithelial atypia diagnosed at core needle breast biopsy.

summary.value:
Upgrade rate of Pure Flat Epithelial Atypia Diagnosed on Core Needle Biopsy: Systemic Review and Meta-Analysis

Authors: Rifat Wahab DO, Su-Ju Lee MD, Bin Zhang PhD, Margaret Mulligan MD, Mary Mahoney MD

Background Information 
Flat epithelial atypia (FEA) is a neoplastic alteration of acini, characterized by replacement of epithelium by one to several layers of columnar cells, loss of nuclear polarity and low-grade cytologic atypia. It often co-exists with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH), lobular neoplasia (LN), and low-grade in-situ and invasive ductal carcinoma.  Recent molecular studies have shown FEA may be a common precursor of the low-grade breast neoplasia pathway. On mammography, the majority of FEA cases present as grouped amorphous microcalcifications. Less often, FEA may appear as an asymmetry or a mass. On ultrasound, it often appears as an irregular mass with microlobulated margins and hypoechoic or complex echotexture. 

FEA is increasingly diagnosed on core needle biopsy (CNB) due to its association with microcalcifications. The management of these patients is controversial, because the reported upgrade rates to malignancy upon excision are widely varied. The primary aim of the study is to identify the pooled upgrade rates for invasive breast cancers and/or ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) on surgical excision after a CNB demonstrates pure FEA. The results of this study will assist in guiding the management recommendation (surgical excision versus close imaging follow-up) for patients diagnosed with pure FEA on CNB.

Materials and Methods:
Study Protocol and Quality Appraisal:
Ethics committee approval is not needed as this is a systemic review and meta-analysis. We will follow the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA), statement to conduct this study. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale will used to appraise the quality of the included studies by two breast radiologists. 

Literature search:
A systemic search will be performed by our Academic & Research Services Librarian in conjunction with the authors by using Pubmed, and EMBASE for studies reporting the upgrade rate of patients diagnosed with pure FEA on core needle biopsy.  Suggested keywords/search strings are: flat epithelial atypia management, flat epithelial atypia upgrade, Flat epithelial atypia and biopsy. The total number of overall studies identified with this search will be document. The PRISMA Flowchart will be used to direct our search and is attached at the end of the protocol.

The first selection of studies will be based on titles and abstracts. These will be screened two authors. Articles that report an upgrade rate for FEA in the abstract or table/figure within the full text will be considered eligible for full review. Only studies in the English language will be included in the review. Studies including all types of core needle biopsies (ultrasound, MRI, Stereotactic, tomosynthesis) were included as well as no limit was set for a minimum or maximum number of patients.  If a discrepancy occurs in the selection of a study, a third reviewer will be asked to review the study.

Studies will be eligible for inclusion in our meta-analysis if the following criteria are met: (a) Pure FEA was diagnosed on core needle biopsy, (b) surgical excision was performed for the biopsied Pure FEA or 2 years of negative breast imaging follow-up, and (C) and upgrade to in-situ and invasive carcinoma was reported.  We defined an “upgrade” as the diagnosis of in situ or invasive carcinoma upon surgical excision. We did not consider LCIS, ADH or any other high-risk breast lesions to represent an upgrade. Studies that will be excluded are: (a) Pure FEA was not evaluated, (b) Studies that did not differentiate Pure FEA from other high-risk breast lesions or (c) no surgical excision was performed or lack of documented 2-year follow-up of negative breast imaging. 

Data Extraction:
For each study included in the meta-analysis the following data will be document:
1.	Date of publication
2.	Study design (Case series, Case Control, cohort, or randomized control trail)
3.	Total number of patients with Pure FEA at core needle biopsy
4.	Total number of pure FEA with upgrade to Invasive carcinoma and/or DCIS
5.	Total number of FEA and ADH on surgical excision.
6.	Technical aspects of the core biopsy:  Gauge of needle
7.	Total number of cases with complete removal of target at core needle biopsy
8.	Authors recommendation for management of FEA

Data will be extracted by two authors. Disagreements will be resolved by a third author. Reviewers will not be blinded to that authors affiliations or journal name.

Primary Outcomes and Secondary Outcomes.
The primary outcome for the study is to determine the overall upgrade rate of pure FEA diagnosed at core needle biopsy to invasive carcinoma or DCIS at surgical excision/ follow-up. Secondary outcomes will include the co-occurrence of ADH with FEA on surgical excision. Also upgrades after complete removal of the target lesion will be evaluated.

Statistical Analysis
The bivariate random-effects model with the DerSimonian and Laird method will be used to calculate the pooled upgrade rate and its 95% confidence interval (CI). The histopathologic diagnosis after surgical excision were considered as reference standards. Those case with references standards were included.

Heterogeneity among studies using I2 statistic will be used. Considered high heterogeneity if great than 50% (for overall upgrade rate per study). Meta-regression analysis will be performed to assess potential moderators of heterogeneity across studies.



References
1.	Simpson PT, Gale T, Reis-Filho JS et al. (2005). "Columnar cell lesions of the breast: the missing link in breast cancer progression? A morphological and molecular analysis." Am J Surg Pathol. 2005; 29(6):734-746.
2.	Verschuur-Maes AH, vanDeurzen CHM, Monninkhof EM et al. (2012). "Columnar cell lesions on breast needle biopsies: is surgical excision necessary? A systematic review." Ann Surg 2012; 255(2): 259-265.
3.	Solorzano S, Mesurolle B, Omeroglu A, et al. “Flat epithelial atypia of the breast: Pathological-Radiological Correlation”. AJR 2011; 197:740-746

4.	Chivukula M, Bhargava R, Tseng G, et al. Clinicopatholoic implications of “flat epithelial atypia” in core needle biopsy specimens of the breast. Am J Clin Pathol. 2009; 131:802-808

5.	Piubello Q, Parisi A, Eccher A, et al. Flat epithelial atypia on core needle biopsy: which is the right management? Am J Surg Pathol. 2009; 33:1078-1084

6.	El Khoury M, Sanchez LM, Lalonde L, et al. Is the outcome at surgery different when flat epithelial atypia and lobular neoplasia are found in association at biopsy? Br J Radiol 2017; 90:20160750

7.	Calhoun BC, Collins LC. Recommendations for excision following core needle biopsy of the breast: a contemporary evaluation of the literature. Histopathology 2016; 68:138-151

8.	Becker AK, Gordon PB, Harrison DA, et al. Flat ductal intraepithelial neoplasia 1A diagnosed at stereotactic core needle biopsy: is excisional biopsy indicated? AJR 2013; 200:682-688
